conclusion: To determine whether the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, we can analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The v-t graph plots velocity (v) on the y-axis and time (t) on the x-axis.
The slope of the graph represents the acceleration of the particle.
From t = 0 to t = 1, the velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s.

premise: The slope of the graph in this interval is 0, indicating no change in velocity.
conclusion: The particle is undergoing constant linear motion in this interval.
From t = 1 to t = 2, the velocity decreases from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.

premise: The slope of the graph is negative and constant, indicating uniform deceleration.
conclusion: The particle’s velocity is changing, which means it is undergoing variable linear motion.
From t = 2 to t = 3, the velocity continues to decrease from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.

premise: The slope of the graph remains negative and constant, indicating uniform deceleration.
conclusion: The particle’s velocity is changing, which means it is undergoing variable linear motion.

premise: In the interval from t = 0 to t = 1, the particle is undergoing constant linear motion. In the intervals from t = 1 to t = 2 and from t = 2 to t = 3, the particle is undergoing variable linear motion due to the change in velocity.
conclusion: Yes, the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
